question: Question_03_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answer and \textbf{show all
your work.} Simplification of the answer is not required.

Evaluate the following integral:

\[\int x \tan^{-1}x\,dx.\]

Note: tan\textsuperscript{-1}(\emph{x}) is also denoted by
arctan(\emph{x}).
sols:
For the integral

\[\int x\arctan(x)\, dx,\]

we start by using integration by parts. Let

\begin{align*}
u = \arctan(x) \quad & \quad v = \frac{x^{2}}{2} \\
du = \frac{dx}{1 + x^{2}} \quad & \quad dv = xdx
\end{align*}

This gives

\[\int x\arctan(x)\, dx = \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{x^{2}}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx\]

To evaluate the last integral, we use the fact that
$x^{2} = 1 + x^{2} - 1$ to see that

\begin{align*}
\int x\arctan(x)\, dx &= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{x^{2}}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\
&= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{1 + x^{2} - 1}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\
&= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}\int\, dx + \frac{1}{2}\int \frac{ 1}{1 + x^{2}}\, dx \\
&= \arctan(x)\frac{x^{2}}{2} - \frac{1}{2}x + \frac{1}{2}\arctan(x) + C
\end{align*}

completing the question.
hints:
Notice that $\arctan(x)$ has an easy derivative. How can we exploit
this?
Try starting with integration by parts.
A clever last trick is to note that $x^{2} = 1 + x^{2} - 1$
